10 stitches were provisionally cast on you are only going to use 9 stitches for this end step when designing the shawl i took advantage of the fact that when exposing the live stitches of a provisional cast on and working in the opposite direction there is always one less stitch than the number initially cast on here is an interesting link with a detailed explanation about why this happens http //techknitting blogspot com/2007/01/knitted-fabric-knitting-up-vs-knitting html first remove the provisional cast on by unzipping the crochet chain a stitch at a time which will result in 9 live stitches being exposed if you used my favorite method for the crochet cast on as shown in the first video link please note that at the little loop at the very end of the unzipping process the one that the waste yarn is hooked around is not used as a live stitch in this design that extra half stitch is used in the video as a way to get back to the original stitch count which is not necessary in this case using 2 dpns the same size as your working needle or smaller place 3 stitches on the first dpn put the next 3 stitches on either a stitch holder or a locking stitch marker and place the last 3 stitches on the second dpn with the right side of the work facing out and the wrong side facing in hold the two dpns together in preparation for the grafting process the 8 20 cm yarn tail from your initial row will be on the right hand side of the dpn closest to you graft the stitches together using a garter kitchener stitch as shown on this video www knittinghelp
